original_fears: Social anxiety in large lecture halls
current_fears: Social anxiety in large lecture halls

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Gregory discussed 1) Stress about student loans affecting academic focus, 2) Anxiety about contacting Professor Chen for mentorship, and 3) Scheduling conflict between financial workshop and study group. Solutions included: structured email templates for professors, alternatives for accessing financial workshop content, and strategies to reduce perfectionism. Gregory responded positively by immediately sending emails to two professors, volunteering for future workshops, and creating an action plan. Evidence of progress includes sending professional emails without excessive editing, implementing email management techniques, and committing to approach Dr. Chen in person with prepared talking points.

fears_materialized.Choosing the right career path: Struggling to draft emails to Professor Chen about AI research paths due to overthinking
fears_materialized.Social anxiety in large lecture halls: Nervousness about approaching Professor Chen at coffee machine (small-scale social interaction)
fears_materialized.Academic failure and poor grades: Conflict between financial workshop and algorithms study group scheduling

challenges_materialized.Financial planning: Deciding between work-study hours vs. internship hunting while managing loans
challenges_materialized.Finding a mentor: Drafting/re-writing emails to Professor Chen and researching other professors
challenges_materialized.Managing student loans: Missing financial workshop due to academic conflict

behaviors_detailed.Participates in study groups: Prioritized algorithms study group over financial workshop
behaviors_detailed.Volunteers for campus events: Offered to help organize next financial workshop during phone call

triggers_specified.Networking events: Emailing professors for mentorship and approaching Dr. Chen in person

Discussed 1) Mentor outreach paralysis (specifically emailing Professor Chen), 2) Student loan stress vs. academic priorities, and 3) Networking anxiety. Solutions included email templates with specific research references, financial workshop alternatives, and role-played academic conversations. Gregory responded positively by sending 2 professor emails immediately, volunteering for financial workshops, and developing backup plans. Progress evidenced by concrete actions: sent emails with follow-up systems, scheduled professor outreach, and created emergency scripts for in-person networking - transforming avoidance behaviors into proactive strategies with measurable outcomes.
